709329f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 9th Street (West)
709329f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, south from W. 9th Street, showing
mainlI, the blockfront between 9th and 8th Streets. These photo-
graphs are possible since the removal of the old ''g1'' line that
formerly darkened the Aenue. The 8th Street station of same was
hhere. A recent City Council resolution has authorized the appella-
tion of ''Village Square'' to the open area remaining.
View 1: April 13, 139
View 2: March 10, 1939
View 3: March 8, 1939
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

709339f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 9th Street (West)
709339f-b.text:
430 Sixth Ave., east side, between West 9th and 10th Streets, showing
a florist occupying an entrance to this building. This structure
formerly bore No. 118-122 Sixth Ave. No. 2 of this set is similar.
September 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

709335f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 9th Street (West)
709335f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from W. 9th Street, showing demolition of
the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line between its 8th and 14th Street
stations.
At the left nargin is a portion of the Jefferson Market
Court. Note the bus at W. 10th Strect and the Empire State Building
tower in the center background.
February 19, 1939
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTION1S

P. L. Sperr  May 17, 1939

709323f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 9th Street
709323f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Avenue, east side, at 9th Street, showing the new West Side
Savings Bank building (erected 1928) on the N.E. corner of 9th
Street. It contains the entrance to the Hudson and Manhattan
railroad to New JJersey.
In the foreground is shown part of the old JJefferson Market
Court House building and the excavation caused by demolition
of the old Jefferson Market and construction of the municipal
subway. On this site the new House of Detention for Women is
to be built. To the right is the 8th Street Station of the
Sixth Avenue Elevated Line.
On the skyline in the left of the picture are 55 Fifth Avenue,
the Consolidated Gas building on 14th Street east of Irving
Place, and the tower of the new 40 Fifth Avenue apartment
building on the S.W. corner of 11th Street. In the right
background may be seen the new One Fifth Avenue apartment
hotel at 8th Street, and the skeleton of the new apartment
building under construction at 1 University Place, opposite
the N.E. corner of Washington Sduare.
December 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

709325f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Christopher Street
709325f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, west side, at the convergence of Christopher
Street and Greenwich Avenue, showing, a diner at the southerly apex,
the new Detention House for Women at the northerly apex, both
opposite the W. 8th Street ''El'' Station. The clock tower seen is
atop the Jefferson Karket Court.
View No. 2 is northwestward from a Vantage point on the east
side of the Avenue, near Waverly Place. In this instance the ''E1''
has been partially razed. Note the iron grille near the curbing.
This is a ventilator shaft for the new subway which at this date
is under construction.
January 7, 1939.
View 2: February 1W, 1939.
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
(3)
A view similar to No. 2 several months later.
The Times of April 4, 1939 reports the renaming of
this. open area as 'Uillage 3quare'' nder local leglslation
introduced by Councilman Howard H. Spellman. This was
arrived at in a contest among villagers conducted by
the Sixth Avenue Association.
It was formerly known as ''Jefferson Market Square''
and is at the intersection of Eighth Street, Christopher
Street, Greenwich Avenue and Sixfh Avenue.
May 13, 1939
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
